Sleep-Related Movement Disorders * Restless leg syndrome * Periodic limb movement disorder * Rhythmic movement disorder Dr Bharath Kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM AASM American Academy of SLEEP MEDICINE --- # Chronic insomnia disorder (1) a report of sleep initiation or maintenance problems, (2) adequate opportunity and circumstances to sleep, and (3) daytime consequences. Duration criterion: 3 months, frequency criterion (at least three times per week) DR BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- # OSA DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA OSA is the occurrence of an average $\ge 5$ obstructive events / hour of sleep with _sleep related symptoms_ or _comorbidities_ or $\ge 15$ such events without any sleep related symptoms or comorbidities. **EVENTS :** (apneas, hypopneas, or _RERAs_) **SLEEP RELATED SYMPTOMS / COMORBIDITIES** * C/o _daytime sleepiness_, _unrefreshing sleep_, fatigue, or _insomnia_ * Awakening with _breath-holding_, _gasping_, or _choking_ * Bed Partner c/o _loud snoring_, _breathing interruptions_, * Associated _HTN_, _CAD_, _DM_, _CHF_, _STROKE_ DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- # CSA Apnea Repetitive episodes of breathing cessation occur in the absence of respiratory effort, is characterized by reduced ventilatory motor output. *Handwritten notes:* Central NO effort ✓ No Airflow ⊖ obst effort ✓ Airflow ⊖ ## Central Sleep Apnea AHI > 5 with > 50% of events being central *Handwritten note:* ABG ## Types of Central Sleep Apnea ### Hypercapnic * **Impaired central drive: WONT BREATHE** * CNS Developmental or degenerative diseases ✓ * Brainstem tumors ✓ * Cerebrovascular disease ✓ * Central alveolar hypoventilation syndrome * **Impaired resp motor control or chest wall restriction: CANT BREATHE** * Neuromuscular diseases * Chest wall abnormalities ### Non hypercapnic *Handwritten note:* Normo/Hypocapnic * Congestive heart failure (Cheyne-Stokes respiration) \* * Renal failure ✓ * Acromegaly ✓ * High altitude ✓ *Image text:* Brain does not signal breathing Open Airway --- Ref: M & N DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FAC --- ## Sleep related Hypoventilation 1. If electing to score hypoventilation, score hypoventilation during sleep if EITHER of the below occur: RECOMMENDED a. There is an increase in the arterial PCO_2 (or surrogate) to a value >55 mmHg for ≥10 minutes. b. There is ≥10 mmHg increase in arterial PCO_2 (or surrogate) during sleep (in comparison to an awake supine value) to a value exceeding 50 mmHg for ≥10 minutes. **OBESITY HYPOVENTILATION SYNDROME** | OHS | Pickwikian synd * _elevated daytime PaCO_2 > 45 mm Hg._ * _BMI > 30._ ✓ * _Exclusion of other causes_ ✓ Patients with other forms of sleep-related hypoventilation _may or may not exhibit daytime hypoventilation_. DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- # Narcolepsy ## USUAL TERMINOLOGY * Narcolepsy Type 1 (Narcolepsy with Cataplexy) * *Handwritten note:* Simple * *Handwritten note:* Checkmark * *Handwritten note:* Underlined "Cataplexy" * Narcolepsy Type 2 (Narcolepsy w/o Cataplexy) * *Handwritten note:* Checkmark * *Handwritten note:* Underlined "Cataplexy" DR. BHARATH RATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- ## SOREM # Narcolepsy-Type 1 * Daily excess sleepiness > 3 months * The presence of **one or both** of the following: * A mean latency of < 8 min on MSLT, with evidence of Sleep-Onset Rapid Eye Movement Periods (SOREMPS) and clear cataplexy. **Cataplexy:** * usually bilaterally * symmetrical, **sudden loss of** * muscle tone * \* CSF hypocretin-1 concentration < 110 pg/mL or < 1/3 of mean in normal subjects (required for wakefulness) ### The MSLT Multiple Sleep Latency Test **CRITERIA** * either two SOREMPS on **MLST**, (OR) * a SOREMP on the PSG coupled with at least one SOREMP on the **MSLT**. ### MSLT Procedure: 1. Lights on 2. Patient awake/light breakfast 3. Electrodes checked/reapplied 4. 20 minute nap 5. Patient awake 6. 20 minute nap 7. Patient awake/light lunch 8. 20 minute nap 9. Patient awake 10. 20 minute nap 11. Patient awake 12. Possible 20 minute nap 13. Patient leaves --- # Narcolepsy-Type 2 Narcolepsy type 2 maintains the same MSLT requirements of a mean latency < 8 min and two SOREMPs (or one SOREMP on PSG and one or more on MSLT). Cataplexy must be absent and cerebrospinal fluid hypocretin-1 levels, if measured, must not meet the narcolepsy type 1 criterion. --- # Restless leg syndrome URGE: Unpleasant sensation, Rest induced, Gets relieved on movement, Evening symptoms + associated sleep disturbance or impairment is required to establish the ICSD diagnosis --- # Periodic leg movement disorder PSG demonstrates PLMS as per AASM The frequency is >5/hr in children or >15/hr in adults The periodic limb movements (PLMs) must be accompanied by sleep disturbance or other functional impairment to establish this diagnosis. --- # SYNDROME Z Syndrome Z is a combination of metabolic syndrome (Syndrome X) and obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA). Metabolic syndrome (MS) itself is a constellation of \* obesity, insulin resistance, hypertension and dyslipidemia. DR. (0 - 4 Hz) | | | | | | | Sleep, dreaming | --- ## Questions to ponder.... * Sleep-History * Sleep-Definition * Functions of sleep * Circadian rhythm and sleep wake cycle * Sleep architecture and stages * Neuroanatomy of sleep * Respiratory physiology in sleep * Classification of sleep disorders --- Sleep History Circadian rhythm in leaves of mimosa plants --- # Sleep History **1729** French astronomer Jean Jacques d'Ortous de Mairan surmises that a day-night cycle exists in mimosa plants. He demonstrates that their leaves open during the day and close at night, even when kept in total darkness. **1929** Electroencephalography (EEG), the measurement of electrical activity in different parts of the brain, is used for the first time by Dr. Johannes Berger. Dr. Nathaniel Kleitman hypothesizes that the human brain has a "sleep drive." **1935** It all starts with fruit flies! Hans Kalmus and Erwin Bünning independently discover the existence of the circadian rhythm in fruit flies. **1937** Dr. Alfred Loomis appears to confirm Dr. Kleitman's hypothesis by defining the brainwave patterns now associated with nonREM, or relatively light sleep. **1953** REM sleep is first detected, contradicting the previous notion that brain activity declined during sleep. Short for Rapid Eye Movement, this is the deepest stage of sleep during which your eyes move rapidly from side to side and most dreaming occurs. --- * **1958** Melatonin, the hormone that regulates the sleep-wake cycle is discovered. * **1962** More research is dedicated to obstructive sleep apnea, a condition that impacts 20% adults between the ages of 30 and 70 years old, inspiring broader studies on changes in temperature, circulatory and breathing during sleep. * **1971** Seymour Benzer and his student Ronald Konopka at California Institute of Technology discover a batch of mutant fruit flies with faulty body clocks. They trace it to a gene known as PER. * **1996** The center of the brain that controls sleep and wakefulness, better known as the "sleep switch" is discovered. * **2007** The American Academy of Sleep reclassifies the initial model of deep stage classification developed in 1968, breaking out the states into three categories: N1, N2 & N3. --- # Sleep- Definition

# Sleep- Definition

* Lies between the continuum of life and death
* State of partial or complete unconsciousness from which a subject can be aroused by appropriate sensory stimuli
* Physiological circadian inhibition of reticular activation system
* Active or passive- dichotomy?

* Energy conservation
* Body growth
* Immune regulation
* Behavioural adaptation
* Growth & Hormonal Equilibrium (during sleep more)

# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   Wakefulness is maintained by activation of the ascending reticular activating system (involving several neurotransmitters glutamate, acetylcholine and the monoamines)
*   NREM sleep onset is associated with a reduction in activation of the ascending reticular activating system and an increase in neural activity within the ventrolateral pre-optic area, anterior hypothalamus and basal forebrain.
*   NREM sleep is triggered by activation of cholinergic neurons in the latero dorsal and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei.
*   The suppression of motor activity in REM sleep is generated by glutamate-mediated activation of descending medullary reticular formation.

---

<!-- Page 25 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   Specifically, there are two ascending pathways: one, a dorsal route from the cholinergic laterodorsal and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei, activates thalamic neurons to promote EEG activity via glutamatergic thalamocortical projections (Saper et al., 2005).
*   The ventral route through the hypothalamus includes the aminergic arousal system that originates from the brainstem with serotonergic (dorsal raphe nuclei), noradrenergic (locus coeruleus), histaminergic (tuberomammillary nucleus) and dopaminergic (ventral periaqueductal grey) neurons
*   Cortical activation during wakefulness is also influenced by orexinergic (hypocretin) neurons originating in the hypothalamus, and cholinergic neurons from the basal forebrain
*   During wakefulness, these pathways allow sensory information to be transmitted to areas of the association cortex via the thalamic gate.

---

<!-- Page 26 -->

The transition between wakefulness and sleep occurs through a process of reciprocal inhibition between arousal- and sleep-promoting neurons by way of a “flip-flop” switch (McGinty et al., 2000).

**Wake**
*   TMN Histamine
*   DR Serotonin
*   LC Noradrenaline
*   LH Orexin
*   VLPO GABA/Galanin (ventrolateral pre-optic nucleus)

**Sleep**
*   TMN Histamine
*   DR Serotonin
*   LC Noradrenaline
*   LH Orexin
*   VLPO GABA/Galanin

**Legend**
*   → Excitatory
*   ⊣ Inhibitory

---

<!-- Page 27 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   This is an all-or-nothing process that prevents the occurrence of intermediate conscious states. At sleep onset, <u>neurons in the ventrolateral pre-optic area (VLPO), anterior hypothalamus and basal forebrain are activated and inhibit</u> the arousal systems detailed previously.
*   In particular, the <u>VLPO neurons containing the inhibitory neurotransmitters c-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and galanin, project to (and inhibit) the wake-promoting regions of the ascending reticular system</u> (Sherin et al., 1998) and the descending brainstem arousal neurons
*   REM sleep occurs with activation of cholinergic neurons in the laterodorsal and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei.
*   This cholinergic activation occurs when withdrawal of the aminergic arousal systems (noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus and serotonergic neurons in the dorsal raphe nuclei) produces disinhibition.

---

<!-- Page 28 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

*   This causes the release of acetylcholine, which triggers the increased neural activity that is a feature of REM sleep.
*   <u>Suppression of motor activity, the other marker of REM sleep, is generated by glutamate-mediated activation of descending medullary reticular formation</u> relay neurons (fig. 1c). T
*   he activity of these neurons is inhibitory to spinal motor neurons via the release of glycine and to a lesser extent GABA (Reinoso-Suarez et al., 2001).

---

<!-- Page 29 -->



# Neuroanatomy of sleep

* Sleep process is regulated by neurons that shut down the arousal systems, thus allowing the brain to fall asleep.
* These neurons are found in the preoptic area of the hypothalamus. These neurons, containing molecules that inhibit neuronal communication, turnoff the arousal systems during sleep.
* Initiation and maintenance of sleep require suppression of activity in the ascending arousal systems. This is accomplished by inhibitory neurons of the ventrolateral preoptic area (VLPO) which remain active throughout sleep

*   Input from suprachiasmatic nucleus- Sleep wake cycle
*   Input from limbic system- Emotional control of wakefulness

<!-- Page 31 -->



# SLEEP ONSET

Wakefulness drive to breathe and behavioral influences cease with sleep onset.

Movement and excitatory input to breathe from other external sensors become minimal or completely absent.

Chemosensitivity also decreases.

Accordingly, respiratory pump muscle tone is reduced, leading to a reduction in minute ventilation.

An abrupt reduction in upper airway muscle tone and protective reflexes - contribute to increased upper airway resistance.

---

<!-- Page 32 -->



# NREM sleep

*   Ventrolateral pre-optic area(VLPO) – thalamus
*   Anterior hypothalamus
*   Basal forebrain

*   The VLPO neurons containing inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA
*   Inhibit wake promoting regions ARAS and descending brainstem arousal neurons.

---

<!-- Page 33 -->



# REM sleep

*   Cholinergic activation in pons and basal forebrain
*   Disfacilitation of muscarinic receptors-upper airway
*   Inhibitory to spinal motor neurons via the release of glycine and to a lesser extent, GABA (Suppression of motor activity)

---

<!-- Page 34 -->



# Sleep architecture

*   Cycles of NREM and REM sleep alternate throughout the night in a predictable manner.
*   Sleep architecture changes with age, drugs and diseases
*   Infants have more REM sleep
*   Ageing is associated with difficulty in maintaining sleep and more frequent arousals.

**The Sleep Cycle Diagram:**
*   N1
*   N2
*   N3
*   REM
*   Light Sleep
*   Deep Sleep
*   Vivid Dreaming

---

<!-- Page 35 -->



# Sleep architecture

Sleep is divided into 2 states based on three physiologic measurements (EEG, EOG, EMG) according to AASM
* NREM Sleep (N1, N2, N3)
* REM sleep – Awake mind & a paralyzed body (paradoxical sleep)

In ideal situations, NREM and REM alternate in a cyclic manner, each cycle lasting on an average of 90-110 mins.
During normal sleep periods in adults, 4-6 such cycles are noted.
The first two cycles are dominated by slow wave sleep (Stage N3 of American Academy of Sleep Medicine), subsequent cycles contain less slow wave sleep.

(Handwritten notes on the top right: 90-110 min, 4-6 cycles)

---

<!-- Page 36 -->



# Sleep architecture

✓ In contrast, the REM sleep cycle increases from the first to last cycle, and the longest REM sleep episode toward the end of night may last for an hour.
✓ First third is dominated by the SWS and the last third is dominated by REM sleep.
* Older rules had four stages of NREM sleep and the current rules, NREM stage 3 and 4 are combined as stage N3
✓ NREM sleep accounts for 75-80% of sleep time
* According to R-K(Rechtschaffen & Kales) manual, NREM is divided into 4 stages (1-4) and to the recent recent AASM scoring manual, it is subdivided into three stages ( N1,N2,N3), primarily based on EEG criteria

# N1 sleep

*   3-8% of total sleep time.
*   Dominant alpha rhythm diminishes to less than 50% in EEG, intermixed with slower theta rhythms(4-7 Hz)
*   Electromyographic activity decreases slightly
*   Slow eye movements (SEMs) occur.
*   Respiration and heart rate becomes regular

($\alpha+\delta$)

# N2 sleep

*   Stage N2 comprises of 45-55% of sleep time
*   It begins after approximately 10-12 min of stage 1
*   Sleep spindles(mostly 12-14Hz) and K complexes(negative sharp waves followed immediately by a positive component) intermixed with vertex sharp waves herald the onset of stage N2.
*   EEG at this stage also shows theta waves, muscle tone intermediate
*   No or few slow eye movements
*   Regular respiration and heart rate

---

<!-- Page 43 -->

Stage N2: K complexes (red rectangles) and sleep spindles (green rectangles).

---

<!-- Page 44 -->



# N3 Sleep

*   N3 or Slow Wave Sleep comprises of 15-23% of total sleep time
*   After about 30-60 min of N2 sleep, stage 3 sleep begins and slow waves
*   R-K Stages 3 & 4 NREM are grouped together as slow wave sleep and are replaced by stage N3 in the new AASM scoring manual.
*   Body movements are recorded as artifacts in PSG recordings toward the end of SWS as sleep is lightening.

**Handwritten Notes:**
*   N1: 3-8%
*   N2: 45-55%
*   N3: 15-23%

---

Stage N3 or slow-wave sleep: numerous delta waves.

---

<!-- Page 46 -->



# REM sleep

*   REM sleep sets the stage for dreams ⭐
*   In 8 hour sleep we will experience 4 or 5 REM sleep STAGES and every time we enter REM, we stay bit longer in it ✓
*   Although the entire nervous system becomes active during REM, movements like walking are absent because the muscles become atonic.
*   REM Sleep is called paradoxical sleep since brain activities during REM are comparable to those during wakefulness ✓
*   REM sleep accounts for 20-25% of total sleep time. (1/4th)
*   Based on EEG, EMG and EOG characteristics, REM can be subdivided into tonic and phasic stages

---

<!-- Page 48 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

*   Suppression of respiratory center (neural) control leading to ↓ TV and MV.
*   Normally 10% ↓ in MV in NREM and 20% ↓ in MV in REM, that in COPD is 20% and 40% in NREM and REM respectively ↓PaO₂ & ↑PaCO₂ also ↓ed
*   Circadian changes in airway leading to mild nocturnal bronchoconstriction
*   ↓ ribcage contribution to breathing and ↓ in accessory muscle activity
*   ↓ FRC because of respiratory muscle hypotonia, cephalad displacement of the diaphragm, and a ↓ in lung compliance leading to V/Q mismatch.
*   This leads to drop in PaO₂ by 3–10 mm Hg and elevation in PaCO₂ by 2–8 mm Hg during sleep.

<!-- Page 55 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

*   Postural muscle tone - <mark>highest in wakefulness, decreased in NREM sleep and minimal in REM</mark>
*   Respiratory muscles with respiratory and non respiratory (postural and/or behavioral) functions - **Intercostal and pharyngeal muscles**
    *   Same as in postural muscles, decreases in activity immediately at sleep onset
*   Respiratory muscles with respiratory functions only - **Diaphragm**
    *   <mark>Lesser suppression of activity in NREM and spared the inhibition of REM</mark>
*   **Phrenic motoneuron** - inspiratory drive from neurons of DRG AND VRG
*   **Hypoglossal motoneuron** - <mark>from reticular neurons which provide tonic drive to respiratory system (so particularly affected in sleep)</mark>
    *   This tonic drive to the pharyngeal muscles which contribute to <mark>baseline airway size and stiffness, is most prominent in wakefulness but withdrawn in sleep resulting in an upper airway more vulnerable to collapse</mark>

---

<!-- Page 56 -->



# Respiratory physiology during sleep

Wakefulness drive to breathe and **behavioral influences** cease with sleep onset.

Movement and excitatory input to breathe from other **external sensors** become minimal or completely absent.

**Chemosensitivity** also decreases.

Accordingly, respiratory pump **muscle tone** is reduced, leading to a reduction in minute ventilation.

An abrupt reduction in **upper airway muscle tone** and **protective reflexes** - contribute to increased upper airway resistance.

---

<!-- Page 57 -->

*During sleep*
*   Control of breathing becomes dominated by chemical input.
*   Ventilatory responses to hypoxia - reduced during N2 and N3. CO2 is the main regulator of breathing during sleep.
*   Though, responses to hypercapnia also reduced lesser extent than for hypoxia. (People can tolerate lower levels of minute ventilation and higher levels of CO2 during sleep than in wakefulness.)
*   Minute ventilation is reduced by 1 to 2 L/ minute, and Paco2 increases by 3 to 8 mm Hg during stable sleep, compared with wakefulness

---

<!-- Page 58 -->

*   NREM sleep - breathing is quite regular
*   REM sleep, by contrast, is characterized by breathing irregularity. Breathing frequency increases, and major variations are seen in breath-to-breath tidal volume.
*   Protective upper airway reflexes also are inhibited. Accordingly, obstructive apnea is common during REM sleep.

---

<!-- Page 59 -->



# Arousals

*   Brief cortical arousals (<15sec) from sleep occur 10 to 20 times / hour in healthy subjects
    *   Frequency increases with age
*   Can occur spontaneously or in conjugation with a sleep disorder(apnea/hypopnea) or periodic limb movement disorder
*   Beneficial - Rapidly resolve blood gas disturbances and alleviate the increased work of breathing during flow-limited breathing.
*   Harmful - Rapid switch from sleep to wakefulness and the subsequent resumption of sleep can be highly destabilizing for respiratory control.
*   Extent depends on - Arousal threshold & Ventilatory response to arousal

---

<!-- Page 60 -->

**AROUSAL THRESHOLD**
* Person with low arousal threshold - repetitive breathing disturbances as the affected person oscillates between wakefulness and sleep.
* Approximately 1/3rd of patients with obstructive sleep apnea has low arousal threshold

---

<!-- Page 61 -->

# VENTILATORY RESPONSE TO AROUSAL:

*   With arousal, the wakefulness chemical control of breathing is reinstated, and the increased levels of CO2 that were tolerated during sleep suddenly become excessive.
*   Upper airway motoneurons are activated, and sleep-related upper airway resistance is rapidly resolved.
*   Arousal from sleep is associated with a rapid increase in breathing
    *   On the resumption of sleep, the previous ventilatory response to arousal can drive Paco2 levels below a critical level known as the apnea threshold.

---

<!-- Page 62 -->

| Parameters                       | Wakefulness | NREM sleep             | REM sleep                       |
| :--------------------------------- | :---------- | :--------------------- | :------------------------------ |
| Respiratory rate                   | Normal      | Decreases              | Variable, apnea may occur       |
| Minute ventilation                 | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| Alveolar ventilation               | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| PaCO$_2$                           | Normal      | Increases slightly     | Increases further slightly      |
| PaO$_2$                            | Normal      | Decreases slightly     | Decreases further slightly      |
| SaO$_2$                            | Normal      | Decreases slightly     | Decreases further               |
| Hypoxic ventilatory response       | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| Hypercapnic ventilatory response   | Normal      | Decreases              | Decreases further               |
| Upper airway muscle tone           | Normal      | Decreases slightly     | Decreases markedly or is absent |
| Upper airway resistance            | Normal      | Increases              | Increases further               |

---

<!-- Page 63 -->



# Apnea threshold

*   Level of PaCo2 below which respiration stops
*   Ranges between 2 to 6 mm Hg below the stable sleep Paco2 level (Evidently similar to the wakefulness Paco2 level).
*   The difference between the wakefulness PaCO2 level and the apnea threshold is termed the CO2 reserve.
*   The lower the CO2 reserve, the smaller is the ventilation required for reaching the apneic threshold and developing central apnea.

# Loop Gain

*   Overall sensitivity of ventilatory control system
*   Controller gain – effectiveness of PCO2 on ventilation
*   Planter gain (effectiveness of ventilation to eliminate PCO2)
*   When FRC and dead space reduced – plant gain is high and apnea threshold is reached fast
*   Cpap – improves FRC and dead space and reduce the plant gain

Oxygen reduces controller sensitivity

Ventilatory disturbance (e.g. hypopnoea) $\rightarrow \Delta V_E$

$\Delta V_E \leftarrow$ Ventilatory response (e.g. hyperpnoea)

Loop gain = $\frac{\Delta V_E \text{ (response)}}{\Delta V_E \text{ (disturbance)}}$

---

<!-- Page 67 -->

LOOP GAIN = **VENTILATORY RESPONSE / VENTILATORY DISTURBANCE**
$\checkmark < 1$ - A stable ventilatory system with low respiratory variability because disturbances lead to smaller responses, assuring a rapid return to a stable pattern.
$\checkmark > 1$ - An unstable ventilatory system with high respiratory variability, in which disturbances lead to disproportionately large responses, resulting in a perpetual waxing and waning pattern.

---

<!-- Page 68 -->

Several factors influence each of the gains:

*   1) **Controller gain** -Sensitivity of the peripheral chemoreceptors to changes in partial pressure of gases, sensitivity of central centres to peripheral chemoreceptors, and the excitability and integrity of the lower motor neurons supplying the respiratory muscle;
*   2) **Plant gain** _lung_ -Respiratory cycle frequency, ventilation-perfusion matching, and dead-space ventilation;
*   3) **Mixing gain** - Circulatory delay time, thoracic blood volume, and brain extracellular fluid volume.

# COPD

*   ✓ In COPD, hypoxemia is more during sleep as compared to wakeful pattern.
*   ✓ During sleep, increased hypoxemia is seen in REM sleep.
*   A majority of patients with COPD have worsening respiratory failure.
*   Also COPD and OSA are both highly prevalent, and thus the coexistence of both disorders, often referred to as the overlap syndrome*.
*   Accumulation of secretions, patients of COPD, showed *increased frequency of arousal and decreased total sleep time.
*   In one of the cross-sectional study of symptomatic patient with COPD, 53% of patients reported insomnia and 23% complained of daytime sleepiness.
*   ✓ In severely hyperinflated patients with COPD, having flat diaphragm, the occurrence of severe gas exchange abnormality is predicted by time spent in REM.✓

# ASTHMA

*Asthma patients have worsening of symptoms during night.*
*Emergency room visits are more common at night. A study reports that maximum deaths due to asthma occur between 6 pm and 3 am.*
*Airway function declines during night, whether the patient sleeps or not, though the decline is exaggerated by sleep.*
*Hence, sleep may be one of the important factors in night-time desaturation and asthma exacerbation.*

# Restrictive lung disorders

A restrictive lung disorder interrupts the continuity of sleep and produce sleep-related hypoventilation and or hypoxemia.
Ventilatory support in restrictive disorders improves daytime sleepiness, daytime hypoventilation, chronic respiratory muscle weakness, exercise endurance and pulmonary hemodynamics.

## OSA DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA

OSA is the occurrence of an average $\ge 5$ obstructive events (-> NO Air flow + Resp effort) / hour of sleep with sleep related symptoms or comorbidities
or
$\ge 15$ such events without any sleep related symptoms or comorbidities.

*   OSA severity is graded as follows: Apnea Hypopnea Index
    *   normal (no OSA; AHI < 5 /hr)
    *   mild (AHI 5-14 /hr)
    *   moderate (AHI 15-29 /hr)
    *   severe (AHI $\ge 30$/hr)



### SLEEP RELATED SYMPTOMS / COMORBIDITIES

*   C/o <u>daytime sleepiness</u>, <u>unrefreshing sleep</u>, fatigue, or insomnia
*   Awakening with breath-holding, gasping, or choking
*   Bed Partner c/o loud snoring, breathing interruptions, ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓
*   Associated HTN, CAD, DM, CHF, STROKE

# ① UPPER AIRWAY DIMENSIONS

*   Upper airway dimensions are **reduced in OSA**.
*   \* ↓ **AIRWAY PATENCY** ✔
    *   ✔ ↓ Airway size: small retrognathic mandible, or by *increased volume* of soft tissues (tongue, lateral walls).
    *   ✔ ↑ Airway length predisposing to collapse. ✦
    *   O ↓ **Lung volume** ➔ less tracheal traction and **reduced upper airway patency**.



## Starling resistor

*   Intraluminal ↑ Pcrit
*   -6 cm H₂O ↑↑ **Pcrit**

*(Diagrams illustrating the Starling resistor model and pressure dynamics in the pharynx are present here. The top diagram shows nasal, collapsible, and hypopharyngeal segments with pressure points (e.g., 0 cm H₂O, Rn, Ro, -ve, ++). The bottom diagram illustrates airflow, transluminal forces, and pressure values in different parts of the airway: Atmospheric pressure -0 cm H₂O, Nasal pressure -0 cm H₂O, Pharyngeal pressure -4 cm H₂O, Pulmonary pressure -30 cm H₂O.)*



# ② UPPER AIRWAY COLLAPSIBILITY

*   ✔ Much of the human upper airway is a **collapsible tube**. (No cartilage) pharyngeal
*   ✔ Pharyngeal **Pcrit** is the pressure at which the airway **can no longer stay open and collapses**. It is a measure of the level of **collapsibility of the pharyngeal airway**.
*   ✔ **A more negative Pcrit : less collapsible** airway. ➔ ⓝ
*   ✔ Normal breathing (*Pcrit < -10 cm H₂O*).
*   And obstructive apnea (*Pcrit > 0 cm H₂O*).

---

<!-- Page 81 -->



# ③ NEUROMUSCULAR FACTORS

*Genioglossus*

*   GG plays a very important role in **upper airway patency** during sleep
    *   Innervated by **hypoglossal (XII) nerve** \*
*   Neural mechanisms **modulating arousal** (serotonergic and noradrenergic neurons) have a **tonic** excitatory influence on genioglossus activity.
*   With the onset of sleep, there is a reduction in **arousal-modulated** excitatory output to the upper airway musculature.
*   During episodes of upper airway collapse, arousal from sleep in response to respiratory activation helps to restore airway patency.
*   Although arousals are not always necessary for recovery from upper airway obstruction, patients with OSA have a diminished ability to restore ventilation without cortical arousal compared with non snorers.
*   At the onset of sleep **GG activity falls farther and more quickly in OSA**
    *   → upper airway obstruction
*   Other factors **muscles may be injured** leading to **reduced contractility**
*   There is also evidence for **upper airway neuropathy** in OSA

# Scoring W

Score epochs as stage W when more than 50% of the epoch contains EITHER a or b or BOTH:

a) **Posterior dominant rhythm** (alpha rhythm) over the occipital region (individuals generating posterior dominant rhythm [alpha rhythm] with eye closure)
b) Other findings consistent with stage W (all individuals)
    * **Eye blinks** (0.5 to 2 Hz)
    * **Rapid eye movements** associated with normal or high chin muscle tone
    * **Reading eye movements**

# Scoring REM

*   **Rapid eye movements (REMs):** Eye movements recorded in the EOG derivations consisting of conjugate, irregular, sharply peaked eye movements with an initial deflection usually lasting <500 msec.
*   **Low chin EMG tone:** Baseline EMG activity in the chin derivation no higher than in any other sleep stage and usually at the lowest level of the entire recording.
*   **Sawtooth waves:** An EEG pattern consisting of trains of sharply contoured or triangular, often serrated, 2–6 Hz waves maximal in amplitude over the central head regions and often, but not always, preceding a burst of rapid eye movements.
*   **Transient muscle activity:** Short irregular bursts of EMG activity usually with duration <0.25 seconds superimposed on low EMG tone.

---

<!-- Page 122 -->



# Scoring REM

Score stage R sleep in epochs with ALL of the following phenomena (definite stage R):
* **Low-amplitude, mixed-frequency EEG activity** without K complexes or sleep spindles
* **Low chin EMG tone** for most of the epoch and concurrent with REMs
* **REMs** at any position within the epoch

# Respiratory events

| | |
|---|---|
| Apnea | Oronasal thermistor |
| Hypopnea | Nasal pressure transducer |
| Respiratory effort | Esophageal manometry |
| Snoring | Acoustic sensor |
| Hypoventilation | Arterial or Transcutaneous CO2 |
| Pulse oximetry | Signal averaging time <3 secs |

---

<!-- Page 125 -->

| Term | Definition |
|---|---|
| Apnea | >90% reduction in flow for >10 secs |
| Hypopnea | >30% reduction in flow for >10secs With 3% desaturation or arousal |
| RERA | Sequence of breaths with increased effort or flow flattening + Arousal |
| Hypoventilation | Rise in arterial PaCO2 to >55mmHg for >10mins (Or) Rise in PaCo2 by >10mmHg to a value more than 50mmHg for >10mins |
| Cheyne stokes breathing | >5 central apneas/hr monitored over 2hrs >3 consecutive crescendo-decrescendo breathing with cycle length 40seconds |
| Arousal | Abrupt change in EEG frequency for >3 seconds preceded by stable sleep for 10 secs |

**Note 1.** Cycle length is the time from the beginning of a central apnea to the end of the next crescendo-decrescendo respiratory phase (onset of the next apnea).

<!-- Page 130 -->



# Scoring Cardiac events

*   **Sinus Tachycardia:** > 90 bpm for adults
*   **Sinus Bradycardia:** < 40 bpm 6 years & up
*   **Asystole:** > 3 seconds 6 years & up
*   **Wide Complex Tachycardia:** Rhythm lasting a minimum of 3 consecutive beats at a rate > 100 bpm with QRS duration of less than 120 msec.
*   **Narrow Complex Tachycardia:** Rhythm lasting a minimum of 3 consecutive beats at a rate > 100 bpm with QRS duration of more than 120 msec.
*   **Atrial Fibrillation:** irregularly irregular ventricular rhythm associated with replacement of consistent P waves by rapid oscillations that vary in size, shape and timing.

---

<!-- Page 131 -->



# Scoring Periodic Limb Movements In Sleep (PLMS)

1. The following define a candidate leg movement (LM) event for possible inclusion in a PLMS series: RECOMMENDED
   a. The duration of the LM event is 0.5–10 seconds.
   b. The minimum amplitude of a LM event is an 8 µV increase in EMG voltage above resting EMG for at least 0.5 seconds.
   c. The timing of the onset of a LM event is defined as the point at which there is an 8 µV increase in EMG voltage above resting EMG.
   d. The timing of the ending of a LM event is defined as the start of a period lasting at least 0.5 seconds during which the EMG does not exceed 2 µV above resting EMG.
   e. A portion of, or the entire, LM event occurs in an epoch scored as sleep.

2. The following define a PLMS series: RECOMMENDED
   a. The minimum number of consecutive LM events needed to define a PLMS series is 4 LMs.
   b. The period length between LMs (defined as the time between onsets of consecutive LMs) to include them as part of a PLMS series is 5–90 seconds.
   c. Leg movements on 2 different legs separated by <5 seconds between movement onsets are counted as a single leg movement. The period length to the next LM following this group of LMs is measured from the onset of the first LM to the onset of the next. (see Figure 6)



## VII. Movement Rules

Figure 6. The first two LMs are counted as one leg movement since the time from onset to onset of the LMs in the left anterior tibial EMG channel (LAT) and right anterior tibial EMG channel (RAT) is less than 5 seconds. The period length to the next LM is measured from the onset of the first LM in the group considered to be a single LM.

The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events, Version 2

# Multiple sleep latency test

*   Objectively measures an individual's tendency to fall asleep
*   Support Dx of narcolepsy and Idiopathic Hypersomnia
*   Strict adherence to the protocol can only make the results valid

---

<!-- Page 133 -->



# Multiple sleep latency test

**AASM protocol**
*   Adequate sleep- documented
*   PSG should precede MSLT
*   Should atleast be for 6 hours for the MSLT to be valid
*   To minimize confounding effects of sleep deprivation on MSLT

**Method**
*   1.5-3 hours after PSG in a sleep-inducing environment
*   Monitoring with all channels
*   Nap session- Latency noted, Continued for 15 mins to note REM sleep

---

<!-- Page 134 -->

# Multiple sleep latency test

*   Sleep latency of eight minutes or less plus **2 or more SOREMPs** support diagnosis of narcolepsy
*   Sleep latency of eight minutes or less plus **fewer than two SOREMPs** support Idiopathic hypersomnia

*   No co-morbid sleep disorders or medical disorders

# Home sleep apnea test

Other indications for unattended portable sleep study:

*   Severe clinical symptoms indicate OSA, and **initiation of treatment is urgent**, and PSG is not readily available
*   Patients are **unable to be studied** in the sleep laboratory (safety or immobility)
*   As a **follow-up study** to evaluate the response to therapy (weight loss, surgery, oral appliance)

**Common Path: Is in-laboratory titration successful?**
- Yes
    - Follow up in 1 to 8 weeks to assess clinical symptoms and response to treatment
        - Tolerant to CPAP
            - Continue settings
        - Intolerant to CPAP
            - Careful re-evaluation of mask/interface problems; treat any nasal symptoms; consider pressure relief strategies or in-laboratory desensitization to CPAP

Clinical Guidelines for the Manual Titration of Positive Airway Pressure in Patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnea

Positive Airway Pressure Titration Task Force of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine

Task Force Members: Clete A. Kushida, M.D., Ph.D., RPSGT (Chair)¹; Alejandro Chediak, M.D. (Vice-Chair)²; Richard B. Berry, M.D.³; Lee K. Brown, M.D.⁴; David Gozal, M.D.⁵; Conrad Iber, M.D.⁶; Sairam Parthasarathy, M.D.⁷; Stuart F. Quan, M.D.⁸; James A. Rowley, M.D.⁹

<!-- Page 168 -->

Figure 2—CPAP Titration Algorithm for Patients ≥12 years During Full- or Split-Night Titration Studies. Note: Upward titration at ≥1-cm increments over ≥5-min periods is continued according to the breathing events observed until ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved.

**CPAP Titration Algorithm:**

1.  **Initial Pressure:** Begin at a minimum of 4 cm H₂O.

2.  **Upward Titration (over ≥ 5 min periods):**
    *   Increase CPAP pressure by ≥ 1 cm H₂O if any of the following breathing events occur:
        *   ≥ 2 obstructive apneas
        *   ≥ 3 hypopneas
        *   ≥ 5 RERAs (Respiratory Effort-Related Arousals)
        *   ≥ 3 min of loud or unambiguous snoring

3.  **Maximum Pressure:** The recommended maximum pressure is 20 cm H₂O.

4.  **Achieving Control:**
    *   Continue upward titration until ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved.
    *   This leads to "Control of breathing events and ≥ 15 min in supine REM sleep."

5.  **Handling Specific Situations:**
    *   **Transition to BPAP:** The patient may be transitioned to BPAP if there are continued breathing events at 15 cm H₂O. This may involve "Exploration of pressure."
    *   **Patient Discomfort:** If the patient awakens and complains pressure is too high:
        *   A lower pressure that the patient reports is comfortable enough to allow return to sleep should be chosen.
        *   Resume titration from this comfortable pressure.

6.  **Stopping Titration:**
    *   If, after achieving control, breathing events re-emerge (e.g., after a pressure increase of ≥ 1 cm H₂O for ≥ 10 min), stop the titration.

---

*   A higher starting CPAP may be selected for patients with an elevated BMI and for retitration studies.
*   The patient should also be tried on BPAP if the patient is uncomfortable or intolerant of high CPAP.

sectionTitle: Figure 4—BPAP Titration Algorithm for Patients ≥12 years During Full- or Split-Night Titration Studi
content:
# Figure 4—BPAP Titration Algorithm for Patients ≥12 years During Full- or Split-Night Titration Studies.



## BPAP Titration Algorithm (Pressure vs. Time)

**Recommended maximum IPAP:** 30 cm H₂O

**"Exploration" of IPAP:**

1.  **Start IPAP at ≥ 5 cm H₂O.**
    *   **If ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved:**
        *   Proceed to **Control of breathing events and ≥ 15 min in supine REM sleep.**
        *   Then, if **IPAP ≥ 1 cm H₂O** is maintained for **≥ 10 min**, continue with another **IPAP ≥ 1 cm H₂O** step.
        *   **Stop if re-emergence of breathing events.**

2.  **If breathing events occur (or 30 min without events is not achieved):**
    *   **Increase IPAP and EPAP by ≥ 1 cm H₂O for apneas, or IPAP by ≥ 1 cm for other events.**
    *   **Check for events over ≥ 5 min:**
        *   ≥ 2 obstructive apneas, or
        *   ≥ 3 hypopneas, or
        *   ≥ 5 RERAs, or
        *   ≥ 2 (3 min of loud or unambiguous snoring)
    *   **If these events persist, repeat the titration step:**
        *   **Increase IPAP and EPAP by ≥ 1 cm H₂O for apneas, or IPAP by ≥ 1 cm for other events.**
        *   **Check for events over ≥ 5 min:**
            *   ≥ 2 obstructive apneas, or
            *   ≥ 3 hypopneas, or
            *   ≥ 5 RERAs, or
            *   ≥ 2 (3 min of loud or unambiguous snoring)
        *   **Patient Comfort Branch:** If patient awakens and complains pressure is too high, a lower IPAP that the patient reports is comfortable enough to allow return to sleep should be chosen, and resume titration.
    *   **Minimum\* settings:** IPAP 6 / EPAP 4 cm H₂O



## Notes

Note: Upward titration of IPAP and EPAP ≥ 1 cm H₂O for apneas and IPAP ≥ 1 cm for other events over ≥ 5-min periods is continued until ≥ 30 min without breathing events is achieved. A decrease in IPAP or setting BPAP in spontaneous-timed mode with backup rate may be helpful if treatment-emergent central apneas are observed.

*   A higher starting IPAP and EPAP may be selected for patients with an elevated BMI and for retitration studies. When transitioning from CPAP to BPAP, the minimum starting EPAP should be set at 4 cm H₂O or the CPAP level at which obstructive apneas were eliminated. An optimal minimum IPAP-EPAP differential is 4 cm H₂O and an optimal maximum IPAP-EPAP differential is 10 cm H₂O.

---

<!-- Page 170 -->



## Grading system:

**A good titration** reduces the overnight RDI ≤10 per hour or by 50% if the baseline RDI <15 per hour and should include supine REM sleep that is not continually interrupted by spontaneous arousals or awakenings at the selected pressure (Consensus).

**An adequate titration** is one that does not reduce the overnight RDI ≤10 per hour but does reduce the RDI by 75% from baseline (especially in severe OSA patients), or one in which the titration grading criteria for optimal or good are met with the exception that supine REM sleep did not occur at the selected pressure (Consensus).

**An unacceptable titration** is one that does not meet any one of the above grades (Consensus).

# APAP titration protocol

*   APAP device at home for 7-14 days
*   Min 5 cms and Max 20 cms
*   Follow up- Data downloaded
*   Pressure fixed at that pressure that reduces the respiratory events 90% of time using P90, P95 and REI
*   Adequacy- REI <10

<!-- Page 175 -->



# Leaks

Leakage can occur in several forms.

**Intentional leak** is the controlled leak from the port on mask interfaces that washes out CO2 and prevents rebreathing.

**Unintentional leak** is characterized as a "mouth leak" (i.e., pressurized air escaping via the mouth when a nasal mask is used) or "mask leak" between the mask and the face (i.e., pressurized air escaping between the mask and the face when a nasal mask or full-face/oronasal mask is used).

**Unintentional leak** can be minimized by mask refit or readjustment, and, in the case of "mouth leak", addition of a chinstrap to reduce mouth opening or switching to a full-face/oronasal mask may be beneficial.

It showed improved oxygenation, decreased arousal index, and increased REM sleep when this leak was minimized.

---

<!-- Page 176 -->



# Leaks

*   Leak is an important factor that must be compensated for.
*   Affects aspects of performance including pressure delivered, cycle and trigger thresholds, and respiratory event determination.
*   If leak is high, auto devices may compensate by lowering the pressure, which may seal the mask and reduce leak.
*   Leak should be under 24 L/min in nasal masks and under 36 L/min in full face masks.

---

# Adherence to CPAP

*   29% to 83% of pts. have been shown to fail adherence to Rx
*   Downloading the CPAP data is as important as measuring BP for HT and RBS for DM
*   Download give you the compliance report
*   It can also identify possible causes of non-compliance e.g. mask leak, discomfort, residual CSA
*   It is also possible to identify device failure

Use of CPAP telemonitoring with an automated feedback messaging mechanism linked to CPAP use improved 3-month CPAP adherence inpatients with OSA.

In this study, telemedicine-based education did not improve CPAP use to a statistically significant degree but did improve adherence to OSA evaluation.

<!-- Page 188 -->



# Complications of PAP therapy

*   Nocturnal arousals
*   Rhinitis, nasal irritation, dryness
*   Aerophagia
*   Mask & mouth leaks
*   Facial rashes / irritation
*   Nasal irritation and rhinitis are treated with heated humidification and use of a nasal steroid spray.
*   Claustrophobia - relieved in some cases by changing the type of mask.
*   Aerophagia can be tackled by altering body position or mask type

---

<!-- Page 189 -->



# Complex sleep apnea

*   **OSA**
    *   Leads to: **CPAP Titration/other treatment**
        *   **If TECSA** (Treatment-Emergent Central Sleep Apnea):
            *   Leads to: **Continue CPAP**
            *   Leads to: **Follow up**
            *   *(Condition: Central events remain/Poor compliance)*
            *   Leads to: **BiPAP-S/T/ASV**
            *   Leads to: **Follow up**
            *   Leads to: **Minimize respiratory events**
        *   **If No TECSA**:
            *   Leads to: **CPAP**
            *   Leads to: **Follow up**
            *   Leads to: **Minimize respiratory events**

---

<!-- Page 190 -->



# Split night sleep study

*   Split-night PAP titration- valid alternative to overnight PSG

*   Mod-severe OSA in first 2 hours
*   3 hours left for CPAP titration
*   First few hours OSA+Cardiac events

(All leading to)

*   Split-night sleep study

# Phenotypes of OSA

*   **High pharyngeal critical closing pressure (Pcrit)**
*   **High loop gain**
    *   (Includes "Hyperventilation" and "Compensatory hypoventilation to restore normocapnia")
*   **Poor upper airway muscle responsiveness**
*   **Low arousal threshold**

# Precision sleep medicine



## Case scenario 1-

A woman in her early fifties with obesity and high BP presents with concern for sleep-maintenance insomnia. Her unattended at-home sleep study shows frequent obstructive respiratory events of short duration, usually associated with arousals. Oxygen desaturation is rare. The sleep clinician counsels her on the natural course of her sleep-disordered breathing and the expected cognitive, mood, and cardiovascular outcomes. There was low arousal threshold and high loop gain in the sleep study report.

How would you treat this patient?

---

<!-- Page 199 -->

A combination therapy of acetazolamide and eszopiclone prescribed
The patient asks about CPAP therapy or an oral appliance? – Clinician advises against it

This hypothetical, near-future case evokes the dream of precision sleep medicine, a diagnostic and therapeutic approach to disentangle a given patient's OSA from the disorder's broad heterogeneity.

<!-- Page 201 -->

Patient education : Behavioural Upper Airway
*   Avoid alcohol, sedatives and hypnotics (↑severity of UA obstruction)
*   Alcohol ↓ UA muscle tone, and increases the frequency of respiratory events during sleep.

Weight reduction
*   Excess weight increases the risk for upper airway collapse - higher extraluminal pressures associated with excess soft tissue and/or fat and the encroachment of the tongue and soft palate.✓
*   Studies show that a 10% weight loss was associated with a 26% decrease in AHI.✓

---

<!-- Page 202 -->



# Bariatric surgery:

*   Bariatric surgery is an effective means to achieve **major weight loss** and is indicated in individuals with
    *   BMI $\geq 40 \text{ kg/m}^2$ or
    *   BMI $\geq 35 \text{ kg/m}^2$ with (HTN, DM, OSA) and in whom dietary calorie reduction have been ineffective.
*   The **restrictive procedures** have the intention to restrict food intake by **reducing the total stomach capacity**, such as **gastric banding**, the **gastric balloon** and **gastric sleeve resection** (gastroplasty).
*   A **malabsorptive procedure** is the biliopancreatic derivation technique, also called the **Scopinaro technique** but can cause **severe malabsorption**.
*   Currently, the **Roux-en-Y gastric bypass** is the most commonly done, and combines restrictive and malabsorptive effects.

---

<!-- Page 203 -->

**Positional treatment:**
* Conservative treatment strategies recommend lateral sleeping position. Its observed that the frequency of apnoea and hypopnoea is greater with a supine sleeping position.
* Suggested for OSAS patients with an AHI in the supine posture that is double or greater than that in the non supine postures.
* This therapy could also be advisable for patients who did not succeed with CPAP, an oral device or any surgical treatment, and have breathing abnormalities in the supine posture.
* Also, suitable for patients without OSA but snoring confined mainly to the supine posture.

---

<!-- Page 204 -->

Different methods have been designed for positional therapy:
verbal instructions,
the classical tennis ball technique,
the positional alarm,
- a triangular pillow with space to place an arm and a soft vest attached to a board placed under the pillow.
A small individual cohort study investigated the effects of elevating the upper body by 60 degree and found a moderate reduction of AHI.

---

<!-- Page 205 -->

Oral devices:
*   It includes mandibular advancement devices (MADs) and tongue-retaining devices.
*   It aim to increase the UA size and reduce the risk of sleep apnoeas and snoring in patients with OSAS.
*   work by advancing the mandible
    *   opening the airway by repositioning the lower jaw and pulling the tongue forward.

# Utility

*   Useful in patients with primary snoring, or those with mild to moderate OSA who prefer an oral appliance to CPAP or
    *   do not respond to, or fail treatment attempts with CPAP.
*   A recent study identified phenotypic characteristics including
    *   lower age, female sex, lower BMI, smaller neck circumference, lower AHI, a retracted maxilla and mandible, a narrower airway and a shorter soft palate $\rightarrow$ a good response to oral appliance therapy

# Surgery of the UA:

Patients unable to tolerate or adhere to CPAP therapy can turn to surgical options as a salvage treatment.
Surgery can also be considered as a first-line treatment in mild OSA and in patients with moderate to-severe disease for whom other noninvasive treatments have failed.
It aims to correct anatomical abnormalities in the UA, contributing to its collapse during sleep.
A discussion between the surgeon and the anaesthesiologist about the pre- and postoperative airway management is required.
The results of surgical procedures for OSAS should be objectively documented by PSG 3-6 months post-operatively.

---

<!-- Page 209 -->



## SURGERY IN OSA

*   UPPP reduces upper airway obstruction by shortening the uvula, trimming the **soft palate**, and suturing back the anterior and posterior pharyngeal pillars
    *   Uvulopalato Pharyngoplasty
*   Maxillomandibular advancement osteotomy advances the **maxilla** and **mandible** to enlarge the **retrolingual** and **retropalatal spaces**
*   Adenotonsillectomy is the first-line treatment in children
*   Electrical stimulation of the **genioglossus** with an implanted pacemaker

# Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty

Dr Bharath Kathi

*   Upper airway surgery for OSAHS is less effective than CPAP and is mostly reserved for the treatment of patients who snore, have mild OSAHS, or cannot tolerate CPAP.
*   Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (removal of the uvula and the margin of the soft palate) is the most common surgery
*   Upper airway surgery is less effective in severe OSAHS and in obese patients

# Hypoglossal nerve stimulation or HNS

(Image description: A diagram showing a person lying down with an implanted device. A **Pulse Generator** is shown in the chest, connected to a **Breathing Sensor** also in the chest, and a **Stimulation electrode** near the tongue. A remote-controlled device is shown on a table next to the person.)

*   The genioglossus muscle is the **largest airway dilator** muscle. Electrical stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve causes **tongue protrusion** and **stiffening of the anterior pharyngeal wall**.
*   This device is implanted in the chest.
*   An upper airway stimulation device sends an **electrical signal to the hypoglossal nerve** → nudges the tongue to move forward and prevents the tongue from blocking the air passage.
*   Used in **moderate or severe OSA unable to tolerate positive airway pressure (PAP) therapy**.

remote controlled device turned on during sleep

In a large, multicenter, prospective, single-group cohort study of carefully selected patients, **HGNS** was associated with **improvements in AHI** (decreased by 68%), oxygen desaturation index (ODI; decreased by 70%), **subjective sleepiness measured by Epworth Sleepiness Scale**, and quality of life, as well as with high adherence (84%).

---

<!-- Page 213 -->



# DRUGS IN OSA

*   Paroxetine (40 mg), Serotonin reuptake inhibitor tried in OSA but had no impact on AHI compared with placebo, in severe OSA.
*   There was a positive impact on respiratory events in non-REM, but not REM, sleep and no improvement in daytime symptoms.
*   Stimulants such as modafinil can be utilized as adjunctive therapy for residual sleepiness in patients who remain excessively sleepy despite adequate treatment for SDB.
*   Doses ranging from 200 to 400 mg daily have been shown to be effective in improving excessive daytime sleepiness in several randomized trials

Currently no drug is actively recommended as a treatment option in OSA. Pharmaceutical agents might reduce sleep apnoea by increasing respiratory drive, changing sleep structure (in particular, suppressing REM sleep), increasing upper airway muscle tone etc

# CSA

Repetitive episodes of breathing cessation occur in the absence of respiratory effort, is characterized by reduced ventilatory motor output.

**Central sleep apnea**
AHI >5 with >50% of events being central



## Hypercapnic

*   **Impaired central drive: WONT BREATHE**
    *   CNS Developmental or degenerative diseases
    *   Brainstem tumors
    *   Cerebrovascular disease
    *   Central alveolar hypoventilation syndrome
*   **Impaired resp motor control or chest wall restriction: CANT BREATHE**
    *   Neuromuscular diseases
    *   Chest wall abnormalities



## Non hypercapnic

*   Congestive heart failure (Cheyne-Stokes respiration)
*   Renal failure
*   Acromegaly
*   High altitude

# EVENTS
(CSA x HF)

*   With the onset of sleep, withdrawal of the wakefulness stimulus occurs and the chemical drive to breathe predominates.
*   Central apneas occur if the arterial PCO2 falls below the “apneic threshold,” or PCO2 level necessary to maintain rhythmic breathing
*   If the magnitude of the increase in ventilation that occurs in response to changes in PCO2 is larger than is needed to achieve eupnea, self-sustaining oscillations in ventilation in which PCO2 is repeatedly driven to the apneic threshold can occur and manifest as periodic breathing
*   Such oscillations in ventilation can also occur when there is a lag between changes in ventilation and detection of the ensuing effects on PCO2 and PO2 by the central and peripheral chemoreceptors, as occurs when arterial circulation time increases. - Happum in CHF
*   Recurrent arousals from sleep can also play an important role in initiating and maintaining central apneas as the state change from sleep to wakefulness re-engages the neurogenic drive to breathe. This can provoke ventilatory overshoot → and help to sustain oscillations in respiration.

# EVIDENCE However, a multinational, multicenter, randomized trial of patients with symptomatic chronic heart failure with depressed LV ejection fraction (≤45%) and predominant CSA demonstrated a lack of efficacy and actually increased cardiovascular mortality among individuals assigned to ASV. After assessing the available current data, the AASM has recommended the use of CPAP or oxygen for first-line treatment of CSR related to heart failure, and recommended against the use of ASV to treat CHF-associated CSA in patients with low ejection fraction and moderate or severe CSA. --- Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) / Pickwickian syndrome OBESITY HYPOVENTILATION SYNDROME * elevated daytime Pa co2 > 45 mm Hg), * BMI > 30. kslm² * Exclusion of other causes 1. If electing to score hypoventilation, score hypoventilation during sleep if EITHER of the below occur: RECOMMENDED * There is an increase in the arterial PCO₂ (or surrogate) to a value > 55 mmHg for ≥ 10 minutes. * There is ≥ 10 mmHg increase in arterial PCO₂ (or surrogate) during sleep (in comparison to an awake supine value) to a value exceeding 50 mmHg for ≥ 10 minutes. --- # OBESITY * **Impaired respiratory mechanics** * (reduced chest wall and respiratory system compliance, increased airway resistance, expiratory flow limitation, reduced respiratory muscle efficiency) * **↑↑LEPTIN** * Hormone produced by adipocytes. Regulates appetite & metabolism * Potent ventilatory stimulant on central resp control nuclei * BUT LEPTIN RESISTANCE DEVELOPS → attenuation of stimulatory effects * Hypoventilation --- *Labels from the visual diagram:* * Obesity * ↑Leptin --- DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FAGE EBARM --- ## CF & Diagnosis * Typical symptoms of OSA plus * additional symptoms of hypercapnia including _morning headaches_, * Pulmonary hypertension, cor pulmonale, and polycythemia are also more common in patients with OHS compared with patients with OSA alone. * Typically, patients manifest a >10 mm Hg increase in their _PaCO2_ during sleep. * The presence of deep _nonobstructive desaturations_ or _lack of SpO2 recovery_ after an _obstructive event_ during polysomnography (PSG) suggest _underlying hypoventilation_ * OHS is a _diagnosis of exclusion_. * Other causes of _chronic hypoventilation_ including significant pulmonary disease, chest wall disorders, _neuromuscular disease_, severe _hypothyroidism_, and other central hypoventilation syndromes must be excluded --- (Rx) Modes and Settings ✓ Per ATS guideline on OHS, CPAP is recommended (rather than NIV) as first-line therapy for stable ambulatory patients with OHS. CPAP relieves upper airway obstruction effectively treating OSA. Although it does not increase alveolar ventilation, it can improve wake hypercarbia by means of unloading the CO2 that builds up during repetitive episodes of flow cessation during sleep. Since OSA is present in more than 90% of OHS patients, it is not surprising that CPAP alone has been shown to be effective in treating of the 60% to 80% of patients with OHS ✗ BiPAP may be required if intolerance at high pressures or persistent hypoxemia or hypercapnia or in OHS with mild OSA --- LETS PROVIDE BEST QUALITY SLEEP DR.
